evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed networking anxiety around job searches and academic pressures. Solutions: Role-played networking scenarios, designed achievable interaction steps ('library hi'), created rejection response plans, and used humor/gestures to reduce tension. Jamie showed progress by practicing multiple conversation approaches, submitting a job application despite fear, creating coping strategies (evidence folder), and planning concrete next steps (lab interaction, response tracking).

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed networking terror and job application anxiety. Solutions: role-playing safe interactions, reframing rejection, starting with emails/quick greetings. Progress shown through successful role-plays (voice strengthening during practice), submitting job application despite fear, recognizing overthinking patterns, and using humor to cope.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Problems: Networking anxiety, fear of rejection, job application stress, and overthinking social interactions. Solutions: Role-playing practice, reframing rejection responses, creating simple openers, celebrating small wins via Awkward Wins folder, and sending one job application experimentally. Response: Jamie actively engaged in solutions - designed openers, successfully role-played scenarios, committed to real-world practice, and sent application. Progress: Demonstrated reduced anxiety through laughter/joking, created actionable plan for lab interaction, documented win, and took concrete action by submitting application.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Discussed networking anxiety and job search fears manifesting as avoidance of coursework. Solutions included: 1) Role-playing low-pressure openers ("How's the assignment going?") 2) Creating "Awkward Wins" folder to celebrate small successes 3) Preparing rejection responses ("No worries!") 4) Using humor (cat resumes) to reduce perfectionism. Jamie actively participated in multiple role-play rounds, progressed from email-only to planning in-person approaches, documented wins via emoji texts, and submitted a real job application despite initial chaotic attempt. Demonstrated concrete improvement through physical gestures during practice (pointing), reframing rejection, and taking action on solutions.
